tasa_website folder (non-package)¶

run.py¶

When the make run command is called in your command line, run.py is used to start the application on a local development server. In run.py, tasa_website package (aka folder is located and the __init__.py file is executed. This binds the objects it defines to names in the tasa_website package’s namespace (e.g. ROOT = 'tasa_website/' is used in views.py when building file paths to reference any images used in the static folder).

from tasa_website import app

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=5000)

Imports¶

import app lets us call app directly in run.py. Writing only import tasa_website would mean we’d have to write tasa_website.app to access the app object inside the :command:` tasa_website` namespace.

Read the section for __init__.py before continuing.

Statements¶

if __name__ == '__main__':

  • When executing a program in Python, several variables, two of which are __name__ and __main__, are immediately set. __name__ is evaluated as the name of the current module (aka file). If the module is run directly (from the command line), __name__ is instead set to the string '__main__'.

  • One such exception to this is seen in our code when a file is implicitly executed like __init__.py is. In this case, __name__ will be set to the package name because when make run is called in the command line, it is run as the main file.

app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=5000)

  • Runs the Flask app on the host on port 5000

tasa_website
